page.title: 06MARAZION MARSH
page.content: The marsh is well known to ornithologists. It is the first and last stop for birds crossing the sea on their Spring and Autumn migrations. Like many other British marshes, parts have been drained for building land. The marsh has a typical wetland flora with many reeds and willowscrub. It formed because sand dunes block the river off from the sea. Herons, coot, swans and gulls are some of the resident bird population. Many waders such as dunlin, greenshanks and redshanks visit the marsh. Ducks include shoveler, mallard and teal. There can be large numbers of snipe at times. Migrants such as sedge warblers and reed buntings come to breed. Rare visitors include Cetti's warblers and bluethroats.
